This is a complete solution. It's trivial to improve upon it by using a better sorting algorithm. It's also trivial to improve upon it by using some kind of stack or queue (for the exchange function) and by having the return values be the number of exchanges needed, rather than success or failure.

The number of elements to be exchanged is unlimited, so using a queue or stack (or some kind of dynamic memory) makes this solution inefficient. It would be better to use a binary tree to implement this algorithm. Then, if there are N elements to be exchanged, it would take (N-1) log2(N) comparisons to exchange them.
